title: 15Â  Dealing with conflicts
text:
15.1 What if you both edit the same file?
When you run git pull, Git will automatically try to merge your local changes with the most-recent version of the file on the Github repo.
Sometimes, two people (or even just you on two different branches) will make different changes to the same lines of a file.
When you try to run git pull, Git gets confused and says:
This is called a merge conflict.

title: 15Â  Dealing with conflicts
text:
15.1.1 What if You Both Edit the Same File?
When you run git pull, Git will automatically try to merge your local changes with the most-recent version of the file on the Github repo.
Sometimes, two people (or even just you on two different branches) will make different changes to the same lines of a file.
When you try to run git pull, Git gets confused and says:

â€œI donâ€™t know which version you want to keep â€” you have to decide.â€

This is called a merge conflict.



15.1.2 Whatâ€™s Really Happening?
When you run git merge, Git is trying to combine the changes from two branches into one. Most of the time, if the changes are in different parts of the files, Git can handle it automatically.
But if two people made edits to the same part of a file (like the same sentence or section), Git doesnâ€™t want to guess whoâ€™s right â€” so it stops and asks you to make the call.
Think of it like this:

Youâ€™re merging two Word documents together.
One version says â€œThe sky is blue.â€
The other version says â€œThe sky is purple.â€
Git says: â€œYou canâ€™t have both. Which one do you want?â€

This is a merge conflict, and Git needs your help to resolve it.
Git will try to merge your changes when you git pull.
If the same lines were changed, youâ€™ll see a merge conflict. Git will mark the conflict in the file like this:
<<<<<<< HEAD This is your version. ======= This is your teammateâ€™s version. >>>>>>> abc123
Youâ€™ll need to manually choose which version (or both!) to keep, then:
git add thefile.qmd git commit -m "Resolve merge conflict" git push



15.1.3 Step-by-Step: Fixing a Merge Conflict
Letâ€™s say both you and a collaborator edited the same section of analysis.qmd and now Git is confused when you try to pull or merge.

15.1.3.1 Step 1: See the Conflict
When you run:
bash
CopyEdit
git pull
Git might respond:
pgsql
CopyEdit
Auto-merging analysis.qmd CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in analysis.qmd Automatic merge failed; fix conflicts and then commit the result.
Step 2: Open the Conflicted File
Open analysis.qmd in RStudio or your code editor. Youâ€™ll see something like:
<<<<<<< HEAD The sky is blue. ======= The sky is purple. >>>>>>> origin/main
This is Git saying:

<<<<<<< HEAD = your local version
======= = the separator
>>>>>>> origin/main = the version from GitHub (or your teammate)

Step 3: Choose What to Keep
Decide what version is correct. You can:

Keep one
Combine them
Rewrite it entirely

The sky is blue and sometimes purple at sunset.
Delete the conflict markers (<<<<<<<, =======, >>>>>>>) when youâ€™re done.


15.1.3.2 Step 4: Mark the Conflict as Resolved
Once youâ€™ve fixed the file, you need to tell Git itâ€™s ready:
git add analysis.qmd
Step 5: Commit the Merge
Now complete the merge:
git commit -m "Resolve merge conflict in analysis.qmd"
ğŸ‰ Thatâ€™s it â€” youâ€™ve handled a merge conflict like a pro.

title: 15Â  Dealing with conflicts
text:
15.2 Tips for Smooth Collaboration

Communicate! Decide who is editing what and when.
Always git pull before you start working.
Commit and push frequently â€” donâ€™t wait until the end of the day.
Avoid working on the same file at the same time.

title: 15Â  Dealing with conflicts
text:
â€œI donâ€™t know which version you want to keep â€” you have to decide.â€




15.1.1 Whatâ€™s Really Happening?
Git is trying to combine the changes from two versions of a file into one. Most of the time, if the changes are in different parts of the files, Git can handle it automatically.
But if two people made edits to the same part of a file (like the same sentence or section), Git doesnâ€™t want to guess whoâ€™s right â€” so it stops and asks you to make the call.
Think of it like this:

Youâ€™re merging two Word documents together.
One version says â€œThe sky is blue.â€
The other version says â€œThe sky is purple.â€
Git says: â€œYou canâ€™t have both. Which one do you want?â€

In Git world, this is a merge conflict, and Git needs your help to resolve it.


15.1.2 How will Git let me know thereâ€™s a conflict?
When Git encounters a merge conflict, two things will happen:

In your Terminal, youâ€™ll see a message like:

Auto-merging filename.qmd CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in analysis.qmd Automatic merge failed; fix conflicts and then commit the result.

In the file with the conflict, Git will mark the conflicted lines like this:
<<<<<<< HEAD This is your version. ======= This is your teammateâ€™s version. >>>>>>> abc123

Youâ€™ll need to manually choose which version (or both!) to keep and then commit the right changes to Git. Weâ€™ll walk you through the process of resolving these conflicts in the section below.



15.1.3 Step-by-Step: Resolving a Merge Conflict
Letâ€™s say both you and a collaborator edited the same section of analysis.qmd and now Git is confused when you try to pull or merge.
Step 1: See the Conflict
When you run:
git pull
Git might respond:
Auto-merging analysis.qmd CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in analysis.qmd Automatic merge failed; fix conflicts and then commit the result.
Step 2: Open the Conflicted File
Open analysis.qmd in RStudio or your code editor. Youâ€™ll see something like:
<<<<<<< HEAD The sky is blue. ======= The sky is purple. >>>>>>> origin/main
This is Git saying:

<<<<<<< HEAD = your local version
======= = the separator
>>>>>>> origin/main = the version from GitHub (or your teammate)

In other words:

Anything between <<<<<<< HEAD and the ======= separator are your current changes.
Anything between the ======= and >>>>>>> origin/main is whatâ€™s on the Github version.

Step 3: Choose What to Keep
Decide what version is correct. You can:

Keep one
Combine them
Rewrite it entirely

The sky is blue and sometimes purple at sunset.
Note: make sure to delete the conflict markers (<<<<<<<, =======, >>>>>>>) when youâ€™re done.
Step 4: Mark the Conflict as Resolved
Once youâ€™ve fixed the file, you need to tell Git itâ€™s ready:
git add analysis.qmd
Step 5: Commit the Merge
Now complete the merge:
git commit -m "Resolve merge conflict in analysis.qmd"
ğŸ‰ Thatâ€™s it â€” youâ€™ve handled a merge conflict like a pro.

title: 16Â  Working with feature branches
text:
16.1 Why Use Branches?
In Git, a branch is like a parallel universe for your code. You can work on a new idea or fix a bug without messing up the main project. When youâ€™re ready, you bring your changes back to the main line with a merge.
Letâ€™s say youâ€™re working with teammates. One of you is writing the introduction, another is cleaning the data, and a third is building plots.
If you all worked on the main branch at the same time, youâ€™d constantly bump into each other â€” accidentally overwriting work or creating conflicts. Branches let everyone work on their own part of the project safely.

title: 16Â  Working with feature branches
section: 16.2 ğŸŒ± Step 1: Create a New Branch
text:
16.2 ğŸŒ± Step 1: Create a New Branch
In your terminal, run the following command to see a list of the branches that exist in your project:
git branch
Youâ€™ll likely just see the main branch with an * symbol next to it. The asterisk tells you this is the branch you are currently working on in Git.
Now, letâ€™s say you wanted to try a new plot, but you werenâ€™t sure if youâ€™re ready to use this in the full project. Youâ€™d like some room to experiment a bit before fully committing your work to the main project. This is where a feature branch comes in.
To make a new branch, run the following command in the terminal:
git checkout -b plot-experiment
You should see a response in the terminal saying something like:

Switched to a new branch â€˜plot-experimentâ€™

This command did two things:

checkout: switched to another branch
-b plot-experiment: created a new branch called plot-experiment

Now youâ€™re in a new â€œsandboxâ€ thatâ€™s separate from your main branch in Git.
To confirm that, run:
git branch
Youâ€™ll see something like:
*plot-experiment
main
Remember, the * shows your current branch. So youâ€™re now on plot-experiment.

title: 16Â  Working with feature branches
section: 16.3 Step 2: Make and Commit Changes on the New Branch
text:
16.3 Step 2: Make and Commit Changes on the New Branch
Now that youâ€™re on our feature branch (which is an exact clone of our main branch at the time it is created), we can begin to safely experiment. You can make changes to our branch without worrying about messing up your work on our main branch.
Letâ€™s try adding some new files to test this out:

Make a new quarto file called 01-plot.qmd
Inside the file, make a new code block cell add the following code:

library(tidyverse)

ggplot(mtcars, aes(x=hp, y=mpg, color=cyl)) +
    geom_point(size=3)

Run the cell, to generate a simple ggplot() scatterplot.
Save the file.

Now, add the new plot file to git, by completing the normal Git workflow steps:

Run git status to see whatâ€™s changed.
Type and run git add 01-plot.qmd to tell Git to start tracking your new file.
Run git status again to make sure your new file showing under â€œchanges to be committedâ€.
Run: git commit -m "Add experimental plot" to take a snapshot of your changes.

Youâ€™ve saved the change only to plot-experiment, not to main. Youâ€™re ready to push your new branch to Github.

title: 16Â  Working with feature branches
section: 16.4 Step 3: Push the Branch to GitHub
text:
16.4 Step 3: Push the Branch to GitHub
Once youâ€™ve committed some changes on your branch, youâ€™ll probably want to back up your work by pushing it to Github.
The syntax to add a new branch to your repo is just like it was when we added our main branch:
git push -u origin branch-name
This command does two things:

Creates the new branch on GitHub
Links your local branch to it.

So if you wanted to add your new plot-experiment branch, for example, youâ€™d type and run:
git push -u origin plot-experiment
Terminal would show a response like:

To github.com:username/my-git-quarto-project.git [new branch] plot-experiment -> plot-experiment branch â€˜plot-experimentâ€™ set up to track â€˜origin/plot-experimentâ€™.*

Youâ€™ll now see the branch listed in your GitHub repo.



Github will display new feature branches in your repository

title: 16Â  Working with feature branches
text:
16.5 Merging back into main
Once youâ€™re happy with your branch changes, you can merge them back into main to incorporate them into your project.
Step 1: switch back to main
Run the following to get back to your main branch:
git checkout main
If you run git branch again, the asterisk should show next to main again.
Heads-up: if youâ€™ve still got your 01-plot.qmd file open in R Studio when you switch back to your main branch, youâ€™ll get a pop-up telling you that the plot file has been deleted (see screenshot). Thatâ€™s because the file doesnâ€™t exist yet on the main branch. Hit the blue Yes button in the pop to close the file. Donâ€™t worry though, the file still exists on your plot-experiment branch because you made a snapshot of your work with your git commit.ğŸ¤ 



RStudio may show a warning when switching branches


Ok, now that weâ€™re on a main branch, we want to bring in the changes from plot-experiment.
Step 2: merge the feature branch into main
Type and run:
git merge plot-experiment
This pulls the changes from your feature branch into the main project.
If everything goes smoothly, youâ€™ll see a message like:
Updating abc1234..def5678 Fast-forward  myfile.qmd | 10 ++++++++++  1 file changed, 10 insertions(+)

Note: If Git canâ€™t automatically combine changes, youâ€™ll get a merge conflict. If this happens, youâ€™ll need to resolve the issues following the steps in the last chapter.

In your R Studio file pane, you should now see the 01-plot.qmd file listed (you may need to refresh).

Next up
Now that you understand the basics of how to make feature branches and have an baseline understanding of how merging works, weâ€™ll show you how to use Githubâ€™s pull request feature to review changes and get feedback (the workflow weâ€™d recommend).

title: 18Â  Quick reference
text: 18.2 Terminology

title: Setup
text:
9.5 Configure git
Here weâ€™ll update some settings within git on your machine.
First weâ€™ll set your user.name so Git knows who you are.

In your Terminal, do this but use your name in quotes instead of â€œMona Lisaâ€:
git config --global user.name "Mona Lisa"
Now weâ€™ll set your user.email.
In your Terminal do this but use your email:
git config --global user.email "email@example.com"
You will want to use the same email when you create your GitHub account.
Lastly weâ€™ll set git to name your default branch â€œmainâ€ instead of â€œmasterâ€ as this is a new standard.
In your terminal, run this:
git config --global init.defaultBranch main
You wonâ€™t get a response unless there was a problem.
In your terminal, run this:
git config --global pull.ff only
This sets a behaivor that is too complicated to explain now, but comes recommended in this very long but thorough explanation.

title: Setup
text:
9.6 SSH Keys
There are a couple of ways to authenticate with Github from your computer. The book Happy Git with R recommends using personal access tokens and I think that is fine, but I prefer the one-and-done nature of SSH keys, so that is the method we will use.

After making sure git is installed, launch RStudio. (If it was already open, quit and re-launch it.)
Go to the menu Tools > Global Options, then click on the Git/SVN tab.
Check the Enable version control interface for RStudio button.
There should already be a path included in the Make sure the path to the git executable is correct.

If it is not, try quitting RStudio and relaunching it and do this step again.
If it is still not there, talk to the prof. Weâ€™ll find it.





Git/SVN window



9.6.1 Create a new SSH key
If you SSH Key path was already filled then you can skip to the next step.
If youâ€™ve never used SSH keys before, youâ€™ll have to create one, but RStudio makes that fairly painless.

Click on the Create RSA Key button.
You should be able to leave all the defaults as they are. Leave the optional Passphrase field blank.
Click Create.
You should see a message that says â€œKey Created Successfullyâ€ and it might show you a pretty picture. Click OK.




SSH Key Creation window

title: Setup
text:
9.7 Saving SSH key in Github
Now weâ€™ll save the contents of that secret file on your computer into your Github account so Github â€œknowsâ€ about your computer.
First we need access to your â€œPublicâ€ key:

In the RStudio Git/SVN window, click on the View public key button.
This will open a new window with the contents of your public key.




Public key example


Youâ€™ll want access to copy that key to paste into Github in the next step:

Go to github.com and click your user icon and choose Settings.
In the user settings sidebar on the left, click SSH and GPG keys.
Click New SSH key or Add SSH key.
In the â€œTitleâ€ field, add a descriptive label for the new key. Name it after your computer, like â€œPersonal MacBook Airâ€ or something.
In the â€œKeyâ€ field, so Command-V to paste your key into the box.

It will look something like this:



Saving the key


Almost done!

Click Add SSH key.
If prompted, confirm your GitHub password.


9.7.1 Test Github connection

From your Terminal in RStudio, do the following command:

ssh -T git@github.com

If you are asked about â€œRSA key fingerprintâ€, type yes and hit return.
In the end, you should have a success message like: â€œHi username! Youâ€™ve successfully authenticated, but GitHub does not provide shell access.â€ If you get that message, you are good!

title: 10Â  Make our Git project
section: 10.2 Run a Quarto File (we can probably skip this..)
text:
10.2 Run a Quarto File (we can probably skip this..)
Before we get into Git, letâ€™s quickly make sure Quarto is working as expected by creating and rendering a new file.

Click the new file icon at the top left of R Studio and click â€œQuarto documentâ€¦â€ (or go to File > New File > Quarto documentâ€¦).
Add a title like â€œIntro to Gitâ€, and click Create.
Save the file, and name it something like 01-index.qmd when prompted.
Click Render in the top bar.

A new browser window should open with an HTML preview of your file.
Great! Youâ€™re ready to start version-controlling this project.

title: 10Â  Make our Git project
text:
10.3 Initialize Git in our Project
If we want Git to start watching our files and keeping track of our changes, we have to make sure Git is connected to our project. To do this, we need to initialize Git inside of our Quarto project.
In basic terms, initializing tells Git â€œI want you to start tracking this folder.â€
How to initialize Git in our new project:

Navigate to the Terminal tab in RStudio.
In the terminal, run this:
git init

If it works, youâ€™ll see Terminal respond with something like:
Initialized empty Git repository in /Users/yourname/my-quarto-project/.git/

Whatâ€™s actually happening here? This command creates a hidden folder called .git in the project folder. This folder contains all the information Git needs to track changes in our project.

text:
10.4 Ask Git what it sees (git status)
Now that weâ€™ve let Git know that we want it to start watching by initializing it in our project, we can check the status of our files by running the following command:
git status
Terminal will return something like the following as a response:
On branch main

No commits yet

Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
        .Rproj.user/
        .quarto/
        _quarto.yml
        my-first-git-project.Rproj
        my-first-git-project.html
        my-first-git-project.qmd
        my-first-git-project_files/

nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
Letâ€™s quickly breakdown what this all means:

â€œOn branch mainâ€: Youâ€™re working on the main branch â€” the default starting branch for development.
â€œNo commits yetâ€: This means Git is ready, but you havenâ€™t saved any versions yet.
â€œUntracked Filesâ€: These are files Git sees in your folder, but itâ€™s not saving changes to them yet. These files are marked in red in the terminal.

The git status command should be used frequently in your git process to keep track of your progress and make sure youâ€™re where you think you are.

git add .
The . after the add means â€œadd everything in this folderâ€ (ignoring anything listed in .gitignore.)
Run git status again
The output should look something like this now:
On branch main

No commits yet

Changes to be committed:

        new file:   my-git-quarto-project.Rproj
        new file:   my-git-quarto-project.qmd

title: 9Â  Installation and setup
text:
9.1 Install the Tools
Before we can get started, weâ€™ll need to make sure that our computers (often referred to as our local machines) are have the tools we need. Letâ€™s do that by completing the following steps:

title: 9Â  Installation and setup
text:
Install Git

Go to: https://git-scm.com/downloads
Download and install Git
Default install settings are fine

Sign up for a Github account:

Go to: https://github.com
Click Sign up
Choose a username and email youâ€™ll remember (youâ€™ll use this in Git config)

title: 9Â  Installation and setup
text:
9.2 Configure Git
After installing Git, youâ€™ll need to go through the one-time process of configure it with your username and email.
Step 1: Start a new terminal session in RStudio
Click on the terminal tab and a new session will be created (if there isnâ€™t one already). The terminal tab is located next to the Console tab.

Tip: If canâ€™t find the terminal tab, go to Tools > Terminal > Move Focus to Terminal .

Step 2: Set your Git username
First, weâ€™ll set your user.name so Git knows who you are.
Run the following command from your terminal, replacing â€œYour Nameâ€ with the username youâ€™d like to use (including the quotation marks):
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
Check to see if you successfully set your name by running:
git config user.name
You should see a terminal response with the username you entered.
If you didnâ€™t get the response expected, then try again. Remember, be careful about punctuation.






Caution



Remember, the username you set here will be visible (read: public) in any future commits you push to GitHub. If you choose to use a nickname or alias instead of your real name, keep it professional enough that you wouldnâ€™t mind a future employer or colleague seeing it if you needed to share your work.


Step 3: Setting your git email
Now weâ€™ll set your user.email.
The email you enter needs to match the one you used to setup your Github account. If it doesnâ€™t, youâ€™ll run into permissions issues later.

In your terminal, type and run the following command, but replace the email with your email (including the quotation marks):
git config --global user.email "email@example.com"







Important



Your git email should be the same as the one you use on GitHub so your commits will be linked correctly. If it doesnâ€™t match, you may run into permissions issues later on.


Step 4: set your default branch
Lastly weâ€™ll set git to name your default branch â€œmainâ€ instead of â€œmasterâ€ as this is a new standard.

In your terminal, run this:
git config --global init.defaultBranch main
You wonâ€™t get a response unless there was a problem.
In your terminal, run this:
git config --global pull.ff only
This sets a behaivor that is too complicated to explain now, but comes recommended in this very long but thorough explanation.

title: 9Â  Installation and setup
text:
9.3 Setup your SSH Keys
There are a couple of ways to authenticate with Github from your computer. The book Happy Git with R recommends using personal access tokens and I think that is fine, but I prefer the one-and-done nature of SSH keys, so that is the method we will use.

After making sure git is installed, launch RStudio. (If it was already open, quit and re-launch it.)
Go to the menu Tools > Global Options, then click on the Git/SVN tab.
Check the Enable version control interface for RStudio button.
There should already be a path included in the Make sure the path to the git executable is correct.

If it is not, try quitting RStudio and relaunching it and do this step again.
If it is still not there, talk to the prof. Weâ€™ll find it.





Git/SVN window



9.3.1 Create a new SSH key
If you SSH Key path was already filled then you can skip to the next step.
If youâ€™ve never used SSH keys before, youâ€™ll have to create one, but RStudio makes that fairly painless.

Click on the Create RSA Key button.
You should be able to leave all the defaults as they are. Leave the optional Passphrase field blank.
Click Create.
You should see a message that says â€œKey Created Successfullyâ€ and it might show you a pretty picture. Click OK.




SSH Key Creation window

title: 9Â  Installation and setup
text:
9.4 Add SSH key in Github
Now weâ€™ll save the contents of that secret file on your computer into your Github account so Github â€œknowsâ€ about your computer.
First we need access to your â€œPublicâ€ key:

In the RStudio Git/SVN window, click on the View public key button.
This will open a new window with the contents of your public key.




Public key example


Youâ€™ll want access to copy that key to paste into Github in the next step:

Go to github.com and click your user icon and choose Settings.
In the user settings sidebar on the left, click SSH and GPG keys.
Click New SSH key or Add SSH key.
In the â€œTitleâ€ field, add a descriptive label for the new key. Name it after your computer, like â€œPersonal MacBook Airâ€ or something.
In the â€œKeyâ€ field, so Command-V to paste your key into the box.

It will look something like this:



Saving the key


Almost done!

Click Add SSH key.
If prompted, confirm your GitHub password.


9.4.1 Test Github connection

From your terminal in RStudio, do the following command:

ssh -T git@github.com

If you are asked about â€œRSA key fingerprintâ€, type yes and hit return.
In the end, you should have a success message like: â€œHi username! Youâ€™ve successfully authenticated, but GitHub does not provide shell access.â€ If you get that message, you are good!

text:

In this chapter you:

Downloaded Git
Setup your Github account
Set your Git username (with an appropriate name or alias)
Set your Git email (using the email on your account Github account)
Setup SSH Keys to authenticate with Github

Now that Git is configured, youâ€™re ready to create your first project.

Next up
In the next chapter, weâ€™ll walk you through creating a new Quarto project with Git tracking from the start using the terminal.

title: 7Â  Welcome
text:
7.1 Who is this guide for?
Welcome to the Intro to Git guide! We hope this guide will be a resource for you to learn the basics of working with version control for the first time.
This guide is for students who know some R and want to learn Git and GitHub to manage and collaborate on R projects (especially Quarto ones). It assumes little-to-no hands-on terminal experience but will encourage building confidence over time by interacting with Github through the command line.
Students who are brand new to the Terminal may also find it helpful to go through the Intro to Terminal section of this book before working through this guide.

title: 7Â  Welcome
text:
7.2 Prerequisites
Before we move on to working with Git and Github, we need to make sure you have what you need to successfully complete the exercises in this guide. The guide assumes you already have the following installed on your computer:

R
RStudio
Quarto

If you are missing any these, please go to the links listed and make sure to install before moving on to the next chapter!

title: 8Â  Introduction to version control
text:
8.1 Introduction to Version control
In this chapter, weâ€™ll talk about the benefits of using version control to track changes in your coding projects. Weâ€™ll also explain how Git and Github allow store versions of our projects online so we can collaborate with others.
What is version control?
Version control is a system that helps you track and manage changes to files over time. It lets you save different versions of your work, go back to earlier versions if you make a mistake, and work with other people without overwriting each otherâ€™s changes.
Imagine youâ€™re writing a paper. Every time you make a big edit, you save a new copy: paper_v1.docx, paper_v2.docx, paper_final.docx, etc.
Itâ€™s easy to see how it could become difficult to keep track of which version was which using this kind of a system. Now imagine how much messier and unwieldy it could be trying to keep track of different versions of an R project with changes in multiple .qmd file â€”> enter version control.
Version control keeps track of these different versions for you. Have you ever used the versions feature in Google docs when working on an article draft? Then youâ€™ve interacted with version control.
What is Git?
To keep track of versions of coding projects, programmers use a version control tool called Git. It runs on your computer and helps you:
You can think of Git like the â€œsave gameâ€ feature on a video game. Instead of saving the progress of your character in your game, Git saves your progress in your coding files. But just like in many games, we have to tell Git when and how to save a new version.
This is where Github comes in.
What is Github?
GitHub is a website that hosts Git repositories (your project + its history) online.
Github lets you:
If Git is a notebook where you track all your work, GitHub is like an online library where you can store a copy of that notebook â€” and invite others to read it or even help you write in it.
To recap:
Next up:
Weâ€™ll get our computers and accounts setup to use Git.

title: 8Â  Introduction to version control
text:
Track changes you make to your project files.
Save â€œsnapshotsâ€ (called commits) of your project over time.
Go back to an earlier snapshot if needed.
See what exactly changed between versions.
Work with teammates without messing up each othersâ€™ work.







Store your Git project safely in the cloud.
Share your project with others.
Collaborate with other people (even if they are far away).
Keep a backup in case your computer crashes.




Version control: Describes the system of tracking changes to your files over time so you can revisit or undo edits, collaborate with others, and keep a history of your work.
Git: a version control tool you use on your computer to track changes.
GitHub: a website where you can upload (and share) your Git projects.

title: 11Â  Add, ignore, and commit files
text:
11.1 Ignoring files
In our last chapter, we ran the git status command to tell us what Git sees within our project.
Letâ€™s take another look at those files now by re-running:
Under untracked files youâ€™ll see a list like:
Notice those .html files in the list? HTML files are the rendered output from Quarto, and they change every time you make a change and click â€œRender.â€
Generally-speaking, we donâ€™t save these kinds of rendered files in our repositories because they change so frequently and can cause a lot of headaches during collaboration.
There are some notable exceptions hereâ€¦
Note for Crit: obviously letâ€™s chat about this part and addressing the Github pages thingâ€¦My general thought with teaching people about github is that we should try our best to teach them best practices before teaching them exceptions to rules because it will help them be better prepared for real-world dev environments

crumbs: 11Â  Add, ignore, and commit files

title: 11Â  Add, ignore, and commit files
text:
11.2 Introducing .gitignore
In a Git project, there are several types of files and directories that you typically want to keep out of our repositories to keep things clean, secure, and easy to manage.
What you ignore will depend on the type of project and the coding languages youâ€™re using, but all Github projects use a file called .gitignore to let Git know what it shouldnâ€™t be tracking in the project.
In general, the following kinds of files shouldnâ€™t be tracked in Github:

Sensitive files: Files containing passwords or private information
Big files: Git isnâ€™t built to keep track of large files.

For R and Quarto projects, this will include the following common files types:

Session and history files: .Rhistory, .RData, .Rproj.user/
Knitting files: .utf8.md, .knit.md
Output/render folders: *_files/ ,_site/, _book/
Editor and IDE Config Files: .Rproj.user/

Donâ€™t worry if you donâ€™t fully understand what all of these files are yet. The important thing here is to know is that there are things we should and should not upload to Git, and the way we keep the things we donâ€™t want tracked out of Github is by using a .gitignore file.
Weâ€™ll set one up for our new project in the next step.
crumbs: 11Â  Add, ignore, and commit files

title: 11Â  Add, ignore, and commit files
text:
11.3 ğŸ“ Exercise: Make a .gitignore
Letâ€™s make a .gitignore for your new Git project from the command line using the touch command.
In the terminal, run:
touch .gitignore
In the RStudio Files pane, click on the new .gitignore file to open it.

Tip: If you donâ€™t see the .gitignore in your file pane, you may need to refresh by clicking the refresh icon at the top right of the file pane.

Once you have your blank .gitignore file open, add the following lines and save the file:
*.html 
_site/ 
.Rproj.user/
Letâ€™s break down what each of these mean:

*.html : Ignore all .html files (rendered outputs)
_site/: Ignore the entire contents of the _site folder
.Rproj.user/: Ignore the hidden RStudio files

Check your Git status again by running:
git status
Remember when we ran git status before and saw our .html files? Now the .html files should be gone from the list of files Git â€œseesâ€ because weâ€™ve told it to ignore these types of files with the *.html line in our ignore file.
Before moving forward, letâ€™s add a few more things to the .gitignore to cover some additional things we want to ignore (donâ€™t worry about understanding what all of these are right now).
Copy and paste the following code into your .gitignore file.
# R
.Rhistory
.RData
.Rproj.user/

# Quarto
*.html
*_files/
*.utf8.md
*.knit.md
_site/
_book/

# System
.DS_Store
Save and close the file.

title: 12Â  Pushing to Github
section: 12.2 Connect Your Local Git Project to GitHub
text:
12.2 Connect Your Local Git Project to GitHub
Navigate to the Terminal tab inside your RStudio Quarto project.
Step 1: Add our remote project:
Type the following command, making sure thereâ€™s a space after â€˜originâ€™:
git remote add origin 
then paste the URL you copied from github.
Your complete command should look something like this:
git remote add origin git@github.com:your-name/your-repo-name.git
Run the command by hitting enter.
Step 2: set our branch to main
Now weâ€™ll set our main branch name to main by running:
git branch -M main
Step 3: set our branch to main
Lastly, weâ€™ll push our main branch to Github by running:
git push -u origin main

title: 12Â  Pushing to Github
section: 12.3 Quick Recap: What Do These Commands Do?
text:
12.3 Quick Recap: What Do These Commands Do?
Ok, we just did a lot there. Letâ€™s pause for a moment and breakdown everything we just did:

git remote add origin ...: Tells Git where your online repository lives (on GitHub).
git branch -M main: Renames your current branch to main (standard practice on GitHub).
git push -u origin main: up a link between your local main branch and the main branch on GitHub. â€œPushingâ€ uploaded your local commits (the ones we did in the last section) to GitHub.

In short, these steps connected your local project to your Github repository, then saved the snapshot you took to the cloud. We also wonâ€™t have to repeat these exact steps ever again when saving snapshots in the future.
ğŸ‰ Congratulations: you now have your first live project is on GitHub!

title: 12Â  Pushing to Github
section: 12.4 ğŸ“ Mini exercise: Explore Your GitHub Project
text:
12.4 ğŸ“ Mini exercise: Explore Your GitHub Project
Go to your repository page on GitHub (or refresh the page if you still have it open from before).
You should see all your project files, including .qmd, .gitignore, etc.
Pay attention to whatâ€™s showing in the file list. Youâ€™ll see some helpful information about the project, including:

Which user made the most recent commit
The commit message
The commit number
The timestamp of the commit In the file list
The commit message and timestamp from the most recent update made to each file or folder.







Note



Not every file will update with each git push. Git only keeps track of changes to files. If you made no edits to a file in a commit, it wonâ€™t change. Timestamps will help you track when updates were last made different parts of your project!

title: 12Â  Pushing to Github
text:
12.5 ğŸ¯ Checkpoint
At this point in the guide, youâ€™ve learned how to:

Create a new RStudio project
Turn on Git tracking with git init
Ignore files (.gitignore)
Stage and commit changes (git add and git commit)
Connect your local project to GitHub
Push your first commit


Next up:
weâ€™ll learn how to make changes, track versions, and collaborate like pros.

title: 13Â  Updating files
text:
13.1 Make a Small Change
Youâ€™ll also practice writing good commit messages and checking your work.
Letâ€™s open your Quarto file you made in Chapter 1 (e.g., 01-index.qmd) and make a couple changes.
Replace the auto-generated text and code blocks in the file with the following:
Under the summary header and description, add a new code block with the following:
Then save the file.
Now check the status in your Terminal again by running:
The Terminal should respond with something like this:
Letâ€™s break this down :

title: 13Â  Updating files
text:
---
title: "Intro to Git"
format: html
---

# Summary

Here is a summary of the `mtcars` dataset.

summary(mtcars)


git status

On branch main
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/main'.

Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git restore <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
        modified:   01-index.qmd


The red text tells us that Git sees that something was modified in your 01-index.qmd.
Itâ€™s under the Changes not staged for commit: section, which tells us that Git hasnâ€™t staged it yet (so it wonâ€™t be saved in the next commit).

title: 13Â  Updating files
text:
13.2 Stage the Change
Now that you know Git sees the change, you need to tell Git, â€œHey, save this file in the next snapshot.â€
Youâ€™ll do this by adding â€” or staging â€” the modified file for your next commit.
To stage your changed file, run:
git add 01-index.qmd
Now, check your Git status again.
git status
You should see your 01-index.qmd file in green, along with following message:
Changes to be committed:
  (use "git restore --staged <file>..." to unstage)
  modified:   01-index.qmd`
ğŸ‰ Great! Your changed file is now staged and ready to commit.

title: 13Â  Updating files
text:
13.3 Commit your change
Now, weâ€™ll save the snapshot of our updated file in Gitâ€™s memory. When we do so, weâ€™ll want to include a descriptive commit message noting what we changed. Git commits always need a message attached to them.
A few best practices to keep in mind with commit messages:

Use present tense: "Add summary of...", not "Added..."
Keep it short but descriptive
Think: â€œWhat changed in this version?â€, write that in the message.

âœ… Good commit messages make it easier for you and others to pick up where you left off. If something breaks during an update or if you need to go back to a prior version, commit messages will help your retrace your steps.
With those things in mind, practice writing a descriptive commit message with your change to the 01-index.qmd.
Type something like the following and hit enter:
git commit -m "Add summary of mtcars dataset"
Terminal will respond with a summary of insertions and deletions in your file.
A quick word of caution about the -m flag and Vim
Git commits always need a message attached to them. The -m flag tells the command line that weâ€™ll be writing our message inline with our command.
If you forget to include that message flag, the Terminal will open its default text editor called Vim. If you find yourself in this scenario and donâ€™t know how to get out, thereâ€™s a section on getting out of Vim in our Terminal Guide.

title: 13Â  Updating files
text:
13.4 Push your commit to GitHub
Now, that our changes are staged and commited, weâ€™ll send the snapshot from your computer to GitHub by pushing our changes.
Push your new commit by running:
git push
Now go to your repository on Github â€” youâ€™ll see your commit listed under the Commits tab and your file under the <>Codetab! (You may need to refresh)






Note



You may be wondering why this push command was shorter than it was last time. In your last push, you needed to connect local project (the one on your computer) to the remote repository on Github and set your main branch.
Since you already connected your Quarto project to Github and set our branch to main, you can just use the git push command now.

title: 13Â  Updating files
text:
13.5 Git workflow best practices
Before we move on, hereâ€™s a few key best practices to keep in mind as youâ€™re getting used to working in Git:

Commit early, commit often: Save your work frequently in small, logical chunks. This makes changes easier to track, understand, and roll back.
Write clear commit messages: Use concise, meaningful messages that explain why the change was made. (e.g., Fix typo in introduction, not just update)
Check status regularly: Run git status often to see whatâ€™s changed and whatâ€™s staged.
Stage changes selectively: Use git add <filename> (instead of git add .) when you want more control over what goes into each commit.

title: 13Â  Updating files
text:
13.6 ğŸ¯ Checkpoint
In this chapter, you learned the basic git workflow:

Make a change to your local project
Stage the changes in git (git add ..)
Take a snapshot of the changed files (git commit -m ...)
Push the changes to Github (git push)
Best practices to keep things clean and manageable

This is the cycle you will repeat over and over again as you work on coding projects using git.

weâ€™ll learn how to make changes, track versions, and collaborate like pros.
